title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods, there is a need for more public health professionals, only 6,000 physicians are board certified in preventive medicine, preventive medicine can help reduce costs spent on chronic conditions, the number of preventive medicine programs and professionals has decreased, preventive medicine physicians play a unique role in serving patients and communities, and a strong public health system relies on a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. Loan payment assistance is available for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of their medical education loans. Physicians must submit an application containing required information to receive this assistance. The cost of attendance at a school of medicine, including tuition, educational expenses, and living costs, is defined in the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for this program. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to support this initiative. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section for a Wellness Program Employer Credit. The new section introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a Wellness Program Employer Credit. The credit is 25% of expenses for a qualified wellness program, with a maximum of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must develop and implement a qualified wellness program and maintain accurate records. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Employer Credit, offering a 25% credit for expenses on a qualified wellness program, up to $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must develop, implement, and maintain accurate records of the program. A qualified wellness program involves health risk assessments and offering preventive services. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Employer Credit, offering a 25% credit for expenses on a qualified wellness program. A qualified program includes health risk assessments, preventive services, annual counseling sessions, and seminars on various health topics. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Employer Credit, offering a 25% credit for expenses on a qualified wellness program. A qualified program includes health risk assessments, preventive services, annual counseling sessions, and seminars on various health topics. Qualified participants must be full-time employees and participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Employer Credit, offering a 25% credit for expenses on a qualified wellness program. Qualified participants must participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs and have a health risk assessment conducted. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Code to include the wellness program employer credit. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Employer Credit, offering a 25% credit for expenses on a qualified wellness program. Qualified participants must participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs and have a health risk assessment conducted. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Code to include the wellness program employer credit. Additionally, a new paragraph is added at the end regarding the determination of the wellness program employer credit under section 45O(a). The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Participant Credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Participant Credit, allowing a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who participate in a qualified wellness program. A qualified employee is defined as a full-time employee who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered through the wellness program. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a Wellness Program Participant Credit, allowing a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who participate in a qualified wellness program. A qualified employee is defined as a full-time employee who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program and has undergone a health risk assessment during the taxable year. A qualified wellness program is developed and implemented by the employer in consultation with an individual experienced in wellness programs and privacy protection measures. The employer must ensure compliance with privacy measures for program participants, conduct health risk assessments, offer at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force annually, and provide counseling sessions on topics like smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program focusing on various health aspects such as physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Qualified participants should include at least 50% of the employer's full-time employees. The eligible employer must implement a qualified wellness program focusing on health aspects. The program should include services and programs in which the employer's employees have participated during the taxable year. This section does not apply in taxable years after December 31, 2012. The amendments made by this section regarding the wellness program participant credit apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
